item.title: Using mutation testing to improve trust in LLM-assisted development
item.description:
I believe mutation testing will grow in popularity due to LLMs.

Let’s say that you have code that needs refactoring, and that you are tempted to use LLMs.

  • You don’t trust the LLM to not change behavior, so you need good test coverage before the refactor
  • You could generate tests, but you don’t trust the LLM to write proper tests

Test coverage is (arguably) more important when the refactor is made by an LLM, since humans are (arguably) less likely to make silly, arbitrary changes to business logic.

item.title: How LLM discussions sound to me (in 2025-06-xx)
Paper Comeback?
item.description:
Small prediction.

I’m suspecting pen and paper as a medium will make a comeback.

Improving image support in llms lowers the threshold of digitizing and should, in theory, allow understanding of structure, layout and non-text.

I enjoy pen and paper as an input medium, but have tried to avoid it since it in my case mostly becomes write-only in practice. But maybe no longer.
